detailsOfAchievement: Animators for Rural Multipurpose Development Society (ARMDS) works with marginalised community especially for the cause of women and children rights, need based community based rehabilitation to the differently abled people (PWDs) striving hard to create eco village, people at risk, helping the children who are in difficult family situation, support the resource poort people who are buried with poverty.

sourceOfFunds.purpose: With the support of government of Tamilnadu, making use of the trained local teachers, we offer them two year training in all the school subjects. After two years, these children are mainstreamed and put in their respective class in the regular school. During two years, we identify slow learners and weak students and give them special attention. We help them to develop their own talents and their skills. We provide residence, food and education with the view to mainstreaming them in two years.

Arpanam Special School for Cerebral Palsied and Mentally Retarded Children is a recognised special school by the Government of Tamilnadu. Forty Three Cerebral Palsied and Mentally retarded children are admitted in the school. Activity daily living skills, physiotherapy, Yoga, cultural activities are taught in the school. Vocational courses like candle making, cover making are given. Two Special teachers and a physiotherapy area appointed who follow them daily. Food and residence are given free.

Arpanam Special School for Cerebral Palsied and Mentally Retarded Children is a recognised special school by the Government of Tamilnadu. Forty Three Cerebral Palsied and Mentally retarded children are admitted in the school. Activity daily living skills, physiotherapy, Yoga, cultural activities are taught in the school. Vocational courses like candle making, cover making are given. Two Special teachers and a physiotherapy area appointed who follow them daily. Food and residence are given free.

In the Residential Special Training Centre we were given the permission for 13 children during the acadmemic year 2018-2019 and we are supported by the government . we had the stduents for fist standard to eight standard. They taught regular school subjectss by the teachers in the residential school. As of regular and normal school, this is residential school also functioned. They had their exams and leave and implement govt schemes are as usual as we see in the normal school.

It is another venture of ARMDS for the Intellectual Disabled Children in our area. Started in the year 2012 we have enrolled 53 Intellectual disabled children, in the first year itself. Through the benevolent support of the honorable Government of Tamilnadu and DDAWO, villupuram. we have offered support for payment of Teachers Salary and Feeding grant. The children from age 6-18 attend the regular therapy offered at Arpanam school. various new techniques and variety teaching aids are used .

In the RSTC of ARMDS we were given permission for 20 children during the academic year 2019-2020. We had the students from 1 std to 8th Std. They are taught regular school subjects by the teachers in the residential school. As of regular and normal school, this residential school also functioned. They offered love and affection in the hostel and their human and psychological needs were meted out. They had their exams and leave and implementation of govt schemes. End of the year mainstreamed.

Conducting consumer awareness seminars on critical issues affecting the consumers 3. Conducting workshops and meetings on important issues affecting the citizens 4. Research on key policy issues, using evidence based approach, including conducting pilot studies, primary and secondary data collection and developing on already available research findings

sourceOfFunds.purpose: we authored a paper that reviewed various assessment tools that could be used to support organisations, researchers, open data leaders, and global development practitioners in conducting assessments to build capacity of open data initiatives.For the purposes of this paper, we focussed on how assessment tools can be used to provide useful insights into the progress, opportunities, risks and challenges of implementing an open data initiative  whether at the national, regional or city level.

We embarked on a campaign to create awareness about the harmful effects of pesticides in food and thus encouraging consumers and farmers to go organic. The main objectives of the campaign were to create awareness amongst the younger generation on the harmful effects of pesticides.

CAG carried out a pilot study to assess the state of governance in transport on principles of transparency, accountability, capacity and participation in Tamil Nadu. The projects broad aim was to understand the formal and informal processes undertaken by institutions responsible for shaping and implementing transport policies and plans.

sourceOfFunds.departmentName: International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Society
sourceOfFunds.purpose: CAG has been working on advocating for road safety legislations with Global Road Safety Partnership. The purpose of the project is to advocate for improved road safety through actions directed at state governments and national legislators in three south Indian states. In association with Thozhan, flyers to educate the general public on the importance of wearing helmets, seat belts, etc. were printed and distributed.

CAG joined and took on the responsibility of anchoring the Initiative on Waste, Informal Workers and Chennais Future, a group of civil society organisations, activists, and researchers, that are working towards the adoption of sustainable and inclusive solid waste management practices in Chennai. The Initiative successfully advocated with the CoC to implement a strategy paper on issuing identity cards to waste pickers so as to recognise their occupation and safe-guard their livelihood.

CAG has been working on advocating for road safety legislations with Global Road Safety Partnership (GRSP). The purpose of the project is to advocate for improved road safety through actions directed at state governments and national legislators in three south Indian states.Our focus is influenced by the federal nature of India, where national laws need to be adopted by states through their own legislations and policies that provide the mechanisms to operationalise them at the sub-national level

The overall objective is to contribute to environmental sustainability and good governance of Thermal Power Plants by using collaborative multi-stakeholder approach to address the impact of existing and proposed Thermal Power Plants (TPPs) in India through a combination of information dissemination, evidence-based research, and advisory and advocacy related activities.
Whose rights to the smart city Research Network

The vast majority of plastic waste originates on land, and reaches the oceans because of unsustainable product design and inadequate waste management systems. It is clear that a dramatic intervention is needed, one which demonstrates transformative zero waste systems at the local level and uses data to drive sustainable redesign of production and consumption.

CAG has initiated a project to empower consumers by educating them about various aspects of the electricity sector. Towards this end, CAG has initiated Electricity Consumer Cells (ECCs) in three districts of Tamil Nadu viz; Tiruvallur, Tirunelveli, and Cuddalore in partnership with three consumer organizations. The ECCs work under the guidance of ECC State Electricity Advisors. Also conduct periodic outreach meetings and capacity building programs to train local communities.
This is an initiative to empower local communities on the EIA process. The purpose of the initiative is to contribute to environmental sustainability and good governance.

Indian cities have the challenge of meeting solid waste management needs in the face of rising consumption, crumbling infrastructure, and under-performing service providers. Against this context, greater attention is being paid to the informal sector, which diverts thousands of tons of waste from Indias landfills daily, with a view to leveraging and developing its capacities.The newly issued Solid Waste Management (SWM) Rules, 2016, instructs local bodies to register and include waste pickers

sourceOfFunds.departmentName: International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Society
sourceOfFunds.purpose: Since October 2015, CAG has been working on advocating for road safety legislations with Global Road Safety Partnership (GRSP). In the past year, CAG has been regularly communicating with Members of Parliament from the South, particularly Tamil Nadu to discuss and advocate for appropriate amendments to the Motor Vehicles Act. Along with the other partner organisations in India, CAG sent comments to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Transport that was reviewing the Motor Vehicles Amendment

CAG undertook a campaign to encourage and educate farmers on the ease of organic farming and vermicomposting and encourage and educate the younger generation on the importance of organic farming and kitchen/rooftop gardening.In this regard, a vermicompost pit was set up in Thiruvannamalai and organic cultivation of vegetables done in land identified in Thiruvannamalai and in Womens Christian College, Chennai.Also there were training sessions on vermicomposting and kitchen gardening for farmer

The purpose of the project is to undertake a survey and develop a chapter on Tamil Nadus energy sector, which will include adoption of clean power sector policies. The approach of the project is to conduct political economy-based assessments of constituencies, interest groups, and stakeholders in Tamil Nadu. Towards this end, CAG developed a chapter on historical overview on the evolution of electricity subsidies in Tamil Nadu.

Reboot and Wikimedia staff conducted in-depth design research with over 100 diverse users in India and Nigeria; CAG worked with Reboot to undertake the research in India. Based on the findings, we identified opportunities for Wikipedia to grow its reach and impact, including through new features, strategies, and partnershipsand through harnessing the passion and energy of its global community.

CAG has co-authored a book chapter with Dr. David Sadoway, NTU Singapore, in which the authors examine contentious questions about the provision and governance of urban public services, including the use of digital or electronic services (e-services) in Indias cities.

CAG participated in a study to analyse the transport budget in the local municipal corporations annual budget of four years (2012-2016). A municipal budget is an important indicator of the direction the city aims to develop in. An analysis of this document would indicate priorities of the local body, types of projects taken to help achieve the set vision and if the intent is aligned with the needs of its residents.

Way Forward Chennai (WFC) is a platform focussed on bringing together individual practitioners and organisations to advocate for inclusive and credible responses to urban disasters by looking at the areas of (a) city planning and development, (b) protection of the natural ecology, (c) disaster preparedness and management, (d) post disaster relief and rehabilitation, and (e) governance. Way Forward Chennai (WFC) is an inclusive and open forum conceived and designed by three core team members

The objective of this effort was to support strengthening of Tamil Nadus electricity planning process to one that utilizes renewable energy and energy efficiency, while expanding access and affordability, and awareness of clean energy solutions.

sourceOfFunds.departmentName: All India Institute of Local Self Government
sourceOfFunds.purpose: The study intended to research the impact of privatization of water supply and distribution on the citizens of Nagpur city and attempted to answer the key question "Is NMC/OCW in a position to deliver 24x7 water supply to all residents of Nagpur city at the end of the transition period?". Nagpur has nearly 30% of its population residing in slums.
